awd_abstract_narration:
Changes in the rate at which glaciers flow into the ocean are a source of uncertainty in estimates of future sea level rise. Surges are brief events during which these rates increase up to 100 times greater than the normal flow rate. Surges, which typically last between a few months and a few years on any given glacier, occur at intervals of decades to centuries. Therefore, few detailed observations of surges are available for study. Negribreen, one of the largest glaciers in Svalbard, has started to surge last summer. This project will collect different data sets that will be used with satellite data to characterize the surging glacier.  The project will contribute to STEM workforce development by supporting the training of a graduate student and an undergraduate student. Observations from this project will be added to an existing website and to develop presentations for the K-12 community.

A combination of observations (laser altimetry, video, GPS data, photographs from small aircraft, and satellite data) and recently developed analysis approaches will be used to develop an understanding of glacier response (deformation, crevassing, acceleration, surge progression in the glacier system, elevation change and mass transfer) to surge dynamics. The principal investigator has been studying the 2011-2013 and 1993-1995 surges of the Bering-Bagley Glacier System, Alaska, using similar techniques and numerical modeling. Bering Glacier is a warm-based glacier and Negribreen a cold-based glacier. Results from the two systems will be compared and contrasted. It is anticipated that characteristics of surges common to different climate conditions may be isolated from those dependent upon specific environmental conditions.

por.por_cntn:
A surge in Negribreen, one of the largest glaciers in Svalbard, was detected in May 2017, which motivated this RAPID. Negribreen last surged in 1935/36, thus there is no modern study on its surge behavior. Glacial acceleration is the largest source of uncertainty in sea-level-rise assessment, as identified by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (in their Fifth Assessment Report 5, 2013), and surging is the least understood form of glacial acceleration. To a large part, this is due to lack of observations of surges especially in large and complex glacier systems. Negribreen is the prototype of an Arctic surge-type glacier, whereas the Bering Glacier System, Alaska (whose recent surges the PI's group studied under another NSF Project) is the prototype of a temperate, subarctic surge-type glacier system. The current surge of Negribreen has provided a unique opportunity to help resolve the largest source of uncertainty in sea-level-rise assessment and this project has provided data and analyses to this end (Figure 1).

The main goal of this project, an NSF RAPID, was the study of the surge of Negribreen through airborne geophysical data collection and analysis of those data, complemented by satellite data analysis.
Airborne geophysical data were collected over Negribreen in 2017, 2018 and 2019 (with the first campaign specifically funded as part of this RAPID). These data include laser altimeter data (for determination of surface height and surface height changes), video data and systematic photography (for documentation of the evolution of the surge), GPS data (for geolocation of the other data sets) and ancillary data registering aircraft attitude (for correction of laser data). In addition, satellite data from the European Space Agency's Sentinel-1 (SAR data), WorldView Imagery (Maxar) and Landsat Imagery (U.S. Geological Survey) were analyzed.

(1) Highlights resultant from the RAPID are the following:Maximal velocities of 22/m per day were reached in July 2017, this means the glacier accelerated to 200 times its normal velocity. The field data collection coincided with this peak acceleration phase. Notably, a surge in an Arctic glacier typically lasts 7-10 years, with the peak acceleration in the earlier years of the surge (Figure 2).

(2) The surge started near the front, but not at the front, in 2016 and has progressed up-glacier in the following years, affecting most of Negribreen by 2020.

(3) The acceleration leads to heavy crevassing. We take a crevasse-centered approach in our analysis (Figure 3).

(4) During the surge, mass gets transferred from the upper glacier to the lower glacier. The surface of Negribreen dropped about 20m from 2017 to 2018, another 20m to 2019, and about 10 additional meter to 2020 in upper Negribreen, depending on location.

(5) Interaction and reinforcement of several complex surge-related processes lead to catastrophic mass loss of glacier ice to the ocean (Figure 4): Mass loss from Negribreen in several months of rapid velocity in 2017 was 5.5Gt, equivalent to 15 micrometers or  0.5-1% of global annual sea-level rise, a huge amount for a single glacier.  This result documents how much a surge in a single Arctic glacier matters on a global scale. A physical-process model was derived (a description of the relevant processes), acting like a vicious cycle that leads to the catastrophic mass loss.

(6) Fractured ice, as forms through heavy crevassing during a surge, has different flow properties than solid ice.

(7) Laser altimeter data and image data can also be utilized to characterize surge crevassing, which in turn allows to draw conclusion on the progression of the surge through the glacier system and changes of the glacier, when considered a dynamical system. These more complex steps involve (a) mathematical characterization of crevasse shapes, pattern and elevation profiles, and (b) numerical modeling of ice dynamics. An example of a classification map is seen in Figure 5. The RAPID has laid the foundation for future analysis and modeling work on surge glaciers.

(8) As a technical result, geodetical accuracy of airborne field data collection was advanced, enabling more accurate comparison to satellite data.


The work was also partly supported by Svalbard Integrated Arctic Earth Observing System (SIOS), it is registered as Research in Svalbard Project RIS-10827 "Negribreen Surge" (2017-2019). The field data collection in 2018 and 2019 was synergetic with  airborne validation of NASA's ICESat-2 project by the PI's group (funded by NASA). Flight support was provided by Airlift and logistics support by the Norwegian Polar Institute.


Figure 1. The fast-moving, heavily crevassed Negribreen (left) during surge in 2017. To right is the slow-moving Ordonnansbreens. Photograph by Ute Herzfeld
[DSC_0169].

Figure 2. Velocity maps for July 2017 and May 2018 derived from Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Data from the European Space Agency's Sentinel-1 satellite.

Figure 3. Crevasses in upper and central Negribreen, July 2017. Photograph by Ute Herzfeld [DSC_0206].

Figure 4. Rapid mass loss through calving, July 2017. Photograph by Ute Herzfeld [DSC_306]

Figure 5. Classification map.
